instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_5S: What is PP5V_5S? This is a typo of PP5V_S5 When you see PP5V_5S, assume they meant to type PP5V_S5.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..

threads.title: Sharing succes <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_5S</SIGNAL> rail
threads.message:
First board repair with a MB air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> solved thanks to forum threads and Louis videos.

Dead unit / no fan spin, however green light in magsafe. Most rails seemed fine however had 2v at <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, followed some tips from Duke regarding missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> from an other topic, discovered my <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> was blown (Thought to myself "oh shit my skills aren't ready to replace a chip at that size, atleast not without a microscope") Took at leap of faith and replaced the damn chip, hoping it would work.

It didn't...... Oh well it was probably due to my lacking soldering skills. However then i noticed the board getting hot and discovered that the <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> Transistor next to it was having a party. Replaced Transistor, crossed my fingers for my skills again aaaand we got a fan spin / working machine.

It probably doesn't seem much to most of you guys here, but as my first board repair it feels fucking great to finally benefit from viewing and reading about all this and do it yourself with succes. I want to thank Louis and Duke for all the help and guides you provide. 

Best Regards
Holmenlund

threads.title: Sharing succes <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_5S</SIGNAL> rail
threads.message: Congrats on the fix. It is good practice if a FET is shorted to replace the FET and also the driver chip. Usually the shorted FET will have taken out the driver chip too.

threads.title: Sharing succes <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_5S</SIGNAL> rail
